title: Company School of Painting - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Painting - Module 2: Historical Appreciation of Indian Contemporary and Miniature Art

questions.question: When did the British East India Company expand its presence in South Asia?
questions.explanation: The British East India Company expanded its presence in South Asia during the late 18th Century, which led to the emergence of Company School of Painting.

questions.question: Why are these paintings called 'Company' paintings?
options: Because they were painted by British artists
Because they were created by a company of Indian artists
Because they primarily emerged under the patronage of the British East India Company
Because they were sold by trading companies
questions.explanation: These paintings are known collectively as 'Company' paintings because they primarily emerged under the patronage of the British East India Company.

questions.question: Which centuries did Company School of Painting dominate the art scene in India?
questions.explanation: Company School of Painting dominated the art scene of India between the 18th and 19th Centuries.

questions.question: Company paintings blended traditional elements from which Indian painting schools?
questions.explanation: Company paintings blended traditional elements from Rajput and Mughal paintings with a more western treatment of perspective, volume and recession.

questions.question: What was the primary medium used for Company paintings?
questions.explanation: These works were done in the medium of watercolour. Paintings were mostly painted on paper but sometimes were also painted on ivory.

questions.question: Where were Company paintings first produced?
questions.explanation: Company paintings were first produced in Madras Presidency and soon spread to other parts of India.

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT a subject matter for Company paintings?
questions.explanation: Indian artists started fulfilling the demand for paintings of landscapes, flora and fauna, images of native rulers, court scenes, historical monuments, festivals, ceremonies, trades and occupations, and portraits. Abstract expressionism was not part of Company painting subjects.

questions.question: What was the nature of subject matters for western patrons in Company paintings?
questions.explanation: These subject matters for western patrons were often documentary rather than imaginative.

questions.question: Besides paper, on what other surface were Company paintings sometimes created?
questions.explanation: Paintings were mostly painted on paper but sometimes were also painted on ivory.

questions.question: Which Mughal emperor's time was important for paintings of birds, animals and flowers?
questions.explanation: Paintings of birds, animals and flowers had been an important genre in Indian art from the time of the Mughal emperor Jahangir.

questions.question: Who was Claude Martin?
options: A British soldier and patron of art
A French soldier and patron of art
questions.explanation: This painting comes from an album made for Claude Martin, the French soldier and patron of art who settled in Lucknow in the 18th century.

questions.question: What is the title of the famous bird painting from Claude Martin's album?
questions.explanation: The painting titled 'A Common Indian Nightjar Bird' is one of the famous paintings from an album by Claude Martin.

questions.question: What style does the 'A Common Indian Nightjar Bird' painting belong to?
questions.explanation: The painting 'A Common Indian Nightjar Bird' belongs to the Lucknow, Company school style.

questions.question: Where is the 'A Common Indian Nightjar Bird' painting currently housed?
options: National Gallery of Modern Art, New Delhi
Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York
questions.explanation: The 'A Common Indian Nightjar Bird' painting is in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.

questions.question: What colors were used to delineate the nightjar bird's body markings?
options: Several shades of brown and black
questions.explanation: Several shades of brown and black are used to delineate the bird's body markings.

questions.question: What feature makes the nightjar bird's eye distinctive in the painting?
options: It has a bright ring around it
questions.explanation: The eye has a bright ring around it and the legs are textured with parallel line markings.

questions.question: Why was the landscape painted at a smaller scale than the bird in Company paintings?
options: The main purpose was to record species new to British observers
questions.explanation: The landscape is only sparingly indicated and is in a smaller scale than the bird. This feature is common as the main purpose of the painting was to record species new to British observers.

questions.question: What technique was used to capture the accuracy of the bird in the nightjar painting?
options: Typical western watercolour techniques with bold strokes and soft tones
questions.explanation: The artist used a typical western watercolour techniques with bold strokes and soft tones to capture the accuracy of the bird.

questions.question: Who painted the famous 'Market Scene' from the Patna Company School?
questions.explanation: Artist Shiv Dayal Lal beautifully depicts the detail and accuracy in the 'Market Scene' painting.

questions.question: In what year was the 'Market Scene' painting created?
questions.explanation: The 'Market Scene' painting was created in the period 1850.

questions.question: What medium was used for the 'Market Scene' painting?
questions.explanation: The 'Market Scene' painting was painted in opaque watercolour on paper.

questions.question: Where is the 'Market Scene' painting currently housed?
options: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York
National Gallery of Modern Art, New Delhi
questions.explanation: The 'Market Scene' painting is in the collection of Victoria and Albert Museum, London.

questions.question: How many women are depicted in the 'Market Scene' painting?
questions.explanation: In this painting, we see four women. Two of them are shopkeepers, and the other two are customers buying grains and fruits from them.

questions.question: What are the women selling in the 'Market Scene'?
questions.explanation: This painting depicts the traditional market scene of Patna in which two women are selling vegetables, fruits and grains.

questions.question: What type of clothing are the women wearing in 'Market Scene'?
questions.explanation: All four women are wearing sarees and ornaments. The depiction of the folds of the sarees is beautifully done.

questions.question: Why is the 'Market Scene' painting bright and colourful?
options: Because of the use of natural dyes
Because of the opacity of watercolour
questions.explanation: This painting is very beautiful, bright and colourful because of the opacity of watercolour.

questions.question: How is the background treated in the 'Market Scene'?
questions.explanation: The background is treated very well by a gradual gradation of colour. There are clouds in the sky.

questions.question: What does 'Miyana' mean in the context of Company painting?
questions.explanation: In the painting context, 'Miyana' means a box palanquin, a carriage carried by humans.

questions.question: How many palanquin bearers are shown in the 'Palanquin' painting?
questions.explanation: This painting shows four palanquin bearers and a 'Miyana' box palanquin with a noble person sitting inside.

questions.question: During which period was the 'Palanquin' painting created?
questions.explanation: This painting was painted during 1815-20 in Varanasi.

questions.question: What style does the 'Palanquin' painting belong to?
questions.explanation: The 'Palanquin' painting belongs to Varanasi, Company School style.

questions.question: What color kurtas are the palanquin bearers wearing?
questions.explanation: In this painting, there are four palanquin bearers wearing white kurtas, yellow and brown dhoti and blue turbans.

questions.question: What color turbans are worn by the palanquin bearers?
questions.explanation: The palanquin bearers are wearing white kurtas, yellow and brown dhoti and blue turbans.

questions.question: What colored cloth did the bearers wrap around their waist?
questions.explanation: They have wrapped a red coloured cloth around their waist.

questions.question: The 'Palanquin' painting is part of how many paintings on modes of conveyance?
questions.explanation: This painting is one of the artwork from the set of forty-two paintings that illustrate conveyance, occupation.

questions.question: What technique is reflected in the 'Palanquin' painting?
questions.explanation: This painting reflects the Indo-European watercolour technique on paper.

questions.question: What characteristic of Company painting is visible in the human figures?
questions.explanation: Realistic representation of human figures and stylization of clothes are characteristics of company painting.

questions.question: How was the background treated in the 'Palanquin' painting?
options: Left alone with only suggestion of shadows
questions.explanation: The overall emphasis was only on the bearers and palanquin, so the background was left alone with only a suggestion of shadows of the bearers and Miyana.

questions.question: What Western treatment did Company paintings incorporate from European art?
questions.explanation: Company paintings blended traditional elements from Rajput and Mughal paintings with a more western treatment of perspective, volume and recession.

questions.question: What was unique about Company paintings compared to photographs and miniatures?
options: They neither had the accuracy of a photograph nor the freedom of a miniature painting
questions.explanation: Company paintings blended traditional and western elements, thus the painting neither had the accuracy of a photograph nor the freedom of a miniature painting.

questions.question: Which city was NOT mentioned as a center where Company paintings were produced?
questions.explanation: Company paintings were produced in Madras Presidency, Murshidabad, Patna, Banaras, Lucknow, Agra, Delhi, Punjab and other centres in Western India. Jaipur was not specifically mentioned.

questions.question: Why did British patrons commission local Indian artists?
options: Because they could depict Indian subjects more accurately being familiar with them
Because there were no British artists in India
Because it was required by law
questions.explanation: British patrons began to realize that their favourite Indian subjects could be depicted far more accurately by native artists who were familiar with them.

questions.question: What attracted British people to commission paintings in India?
options: The diversity of India's people, monuments, landscapes, flora and fauna
questions.explanation: The British people were fascinated and attracted towards the diversity of India's people, its magnificent monuments and its beautiful landscapes, flora and fauna.

questions.question: Why couldn't all British employees afford noted British artists?
options: British artists refused to come to India
There were no British artists available
questions.explanation: They wished to capture these images but not all of them could afford to buy the works of noted British artists. As a result, they started commissioning local Indian artists.

questions.question: What was the intended use for Company paintings?
options: For mementoes and souvenirs for friends and relatives in England
questions.explanation: They wished to capture these images and were keen to collect them as mementoes and souvenirs for their friends and relatives in England.

questions.question: What size were Company paintings typically made?
options: Small, intended to keep in albums
questions.explanation: These paintings were small, intended to keep in albums.

questions.question: How did Company paintings create depth in the background?
questions.explanation: Beautiful tonal gradation created depth in the background of Company paintings.

questions.question: What was emphasized in the nightjar bird painting?
options: Great attention to detail in each feather
questions.explanation: The bird is executed with great attention to detail. Each feather has been outlined and painted with a subtle gradation of colours.

questions.question: What type of line markings were used for the nightjar bird's legs?
questions.explanation: The eye has a bright ring around it and the legs are textured with parallel line markings.

questions.question: What does the painting 'Market Scene' reflect about contemporary life?
options: The contemporary life-style of that period
questions.explanation: Overall, the painting creates a beautiful environment and reflects the contemporary life-style of that period.
